content:
I've recently been using the MvPolynomial and I'm surprised to find that there actually isn't a GradedAlgebra instance on it. However, after some more searching, an instance named AddMonoidAlgebra.gradeBy.gradedAlgebra has been found in the folder about AddMonoidAlgebra. Since The MvPolynomial is defined as an AddMonoidAlgebra, I think probably redefining the MvPolynomial.homogeneousSubmodule as a special example of AddMonoidAlgebra.gradeBy will enable us to directly use the instance on AddMonoidAlgebra.
So, I'm wondering why would things be like this. Is this because of some consideration when designing the APIs? Thanks for your help in advance!

There is a graded algebra structure defined, it's just not an instance because sometimes you want a more general grading (where the variables don't have degree 1). For this reason we don't want a default graded algebra structure which is why it's off by default. You can switch it on with attribute [local instance] whatever_it's_called and you can probably find it with leansearch.net
(sorry on mobile and on the move) my loogle-fu is weak but let me try
Second one has deg(X_i)=1 for all I, make it a local instance
Wang Jingting has marked this topic as resolved.
Thanks a lot! Sorry I didn't notice that these structures don't come as instances.

No need to apologise! This is a "gotcha" because we need to deal with the weighted case, it's not at all obvious that this is what's happening and your conclusion ("the instance is missing completely") is totally reasonable given the information you had.
